courseDescription: Want to improve on your presentation skills? In this course, we will go over the fundamentals of building a stronger presentation. We will be learning about the different tools in Google Slides and use them to design our own slide decks. Through practicing with peers and getting feedback, you can hone your presentation skills and prepare you for your next big presentation!
courseTitle: Building A Stronger Presentation

courseDescription: This workshop will present major protests in French history, such as the French Revolution. We will see how public revolts changed the course of history in France and therefore, Europe. From public figures to a country, people express their opinion: we will see how they impacted their situation.
courseTitle: French History : How Revolts Changed The World

courseDescription: Everything you ever wanted to know about DNA, from the ground up. You need no previous experience in genetics. We will start from the beginning , with: The basic chemistry of the DNA molecule, To how DNA is used to make proteins (The Central Dogma), To the discovery and biology of the gene, To the structure of genomes, To the regulation of gene expression, To how a genome can direct the formation of a human (developmental biology), to viruses, to viroids, to incredibly rare inherited diseases, to how to manually engineer entire organisms. Yep. Everything about DNA that I (a DNA fanatic) can think to squeeze into two weeks. It seems like a lot of information, but we will digest it piece by piece with interactive Socrative polls and visuals. By the end of this course, you will be able to grasp the incredibly delicate complexity of genome structure and the coordinated web of activity that is gene expression regulation - you will understand why a banana and a human being can share 60% of their genetic information, yet be completely different life forms. And you will know how to alter the genetic code manually.
courseTitle: DNA and Genomes

courseDescription: Everyone is told to be confident and believe in his or herself, but what even is confidence? How do I get as confident as I want to be? Understanding confidence is the first step to building it. Step out of your comfort zone and join this workshop! Let's get active and personal :)
courseTitle: Confidence 101

courseDescription: Ever wondered how to make a song, from start to finish? In this course, students will learn to write, record, produce, mix, and master their own songs in Apple's Garageband, a very powerful (yet often overlooked) digital audio workstation. The course will cover basic music theory, easy home-recording techniques, mixing techniques (equalization, compression, modulation), and easy distribution methods for the independent bedroom producer. Experience with a musical instrument is helpful, but not required.
courseTitle: Introduction to Music Production with Garageband

courseDescription: If you're curious about Asian cooking and baking, this is the right seminar for you! From the iconic bubble tea to a multi-layered matcha crepe cake, and a Japanese twist on classic cheesecake, this seminar welcomes chefs and bakers of all levels. Subtle Asian Baking & Cooking is a relaxing and fun seminar for you!
courseTitle: Subtle Asian Cooking & Baking

courseDescription: CALLING ALL STUDENTS WHO NEED TO GET INTO COLLEGE AND HAVE NO IDEA WHAT THEY'RE DOING* Listen, I've been through this, and many others have as well. Choosing the right college can feel like such a permanent decision, and this course explores how to select a college or university out of the hundreds out there. This class will cover the types of collegiate institutions, the college list, recommendation letters, and general financial aid (need based vs. need blind vs. merit based vs. a bunch of other confusing money words).
courseTitle: I Need to Get Into College...Send Help

courseDescription: Ever wondered what it takes to run a successful business? There seems to be so many factors in play, from unstable politics and social movements to ethical dilemmas. This course will help students learn about existing businesses and how they deal with political risk and strategies. By doing in-depth case studies of strong and weak business moves by real companies, students will be able to learn what questions to ask when facing risk and what strategies work best in the business world. Case studies will be about companies like FedEx, SeaWorld, Johnson & Johnson, Best Buy, IKEA, and Royal Caribbean International.
courseTitle: Understanding Business Strategy and Risk: Why FedEx Won and SeaWorld Lost the Business Game

courseDescription: This seminar would evaluate the morphology of the English Language by comparing and contrasting similar languages. Being an intermediate between a Germanic and Romantic language, English is difficult language to master, even as a native speaker. Aiming to increase the language arts and foreign language skills of the students, this seminar would employ an exegetical method to discovering the qualities of language. Topics might include word order, article adjectives (epenthesis, location), qualities of nouns (case, number, gender), and verb usage (tense, noun agreement, valency, voice, mood)
courseTitle: Understanding English through its Roots: Romantic, Germanic, and Indo-European Language Families

courseDescription: In Basics of Legal Reasoning we will be discussing the methods used in analyzing legal writing and judgements. We’ll be starting off with an introduction to the U.S. Constitution and how it is shaped and developed through Supreme Court judgements. Afterwards, we will be taking recent decisions regarding the 4th amendment and creating case notes in groups. This activity will help develop critical reading and reasoning skills, as well as help with understanding by providing a group environment in which they can discuss what they are reading. We hope to finish off the session through a small debate regarding the same amendment and splitting the class into two groups.
courseTitle: Basics of Legal Reasoning

courseDescription:
Song Yuan Ming Qing Chinese landscape painting, Ming Qing calligraphy, Tang Song poem, Suzhou Traditional Gardens, ancient street and alley names… Walking through towns and museums…
 
Black and White—for roof and wall, for ink and paper, for paint and tablet…
Square and Circle—for the shapes of ponds, for the patterns of gates, for the strokes of Han characters, for impartiality and modesty…
Artificial and Natural—for building a verdant hill by hand, for finding a lake stone like a painting…
Bold, Unconstrained and Graceful, Restrained—for poems about Five Sacred Mountains and Yellow and Yangtze River, fearlessly facing any enemies and hierarchies, embracing only freedom and individuality; for poems about exquisite scenes at the windows and elaborate decorations at the gardens, melancholy recollecting the shattered pieces of the shining past, submerging in loss and pain hoping never wake up again…
What? Because contradiction is everywhere.
 
Four characters—Wintersweet, Orchid, Bamboo, Chrysanthemum
Three blessings—Bat, Deer, Crane                
Upturned eaves and flying buttresses, porous stones and ripple wood, dragon gowns and phoenix hats, in all details there are some stories.
Why? Because metaphor is everywhere.
 
From oracle bone script to regular print script, from stone and bronze ages to the time of technology, from narrow alley of width of one’s arm span to the grand avenue of width of fifteen cars, what have been lost and preserved, what have been rejected and inherited, what have been a regret and an honor?
 
When walking through towns and museums, we walk through times and ideas. We bricolage different forms of art and history and communicate with their words and our sentences.
 
We hope this glimpse would lead to gates of gazillion.
courseTitle: Chinese Classical Culture: Communicating & Collaging

courseDescription: The Intro to Python course offers a powerful introduction to programming and teaches the fundamentals of Python. The concepts taught in this course can be applied to most programming languages, and will give students a head start in computer science. Students will learn about data types, loops, objects, functions, classes, and various python libraries. Throughout the course, students will use the skills they've acquired in class to create several personal coding projects, like video games and cool data visualizations.
courseTitle: Intro to Python

courseDescription: Have you ever wanted to publish your own book on a credible platform but felt like it was an impossible feat? This 5-week course will help you with just that! It will cover tips and tricks to self-publishing on platforms such as Wattpad and Amazon Kindle Direct Publishing through 5 interactive 1-hour sessions where you will brainstorm ideas, learn how to market your book via social media, provide a specific step by step guide to publishing on these two platforms and join a group of like-minded individuals to build your confidence in your writing. By the end of this course, you will hopefully have thought of a plausible novel idea, gain extensive knowledge in digital marketing techniques, and be on your way to publishing! These sessions will contain lots of opportunities for one on one advice and group discussions where you can discuss your ideas with the group. No prior writing experience is required.
courseTitle: How To Create and Publish A Book People Will Read

courseDescription:
This course aims to give students:

  -   An intuitive grasp of the physiology of anatomical systems including the brain, heart, lungs, and more, as well as common diseases that affect these systems

  -   The chance to practice design thinking and prototyping as an approach to solving problems in health

  -   A survey of leading medical technologies and what design choices make these treatments so effective

  -   An understanding of the medical tech environment and its educational and career pathways
courseTitle: Human Systems and Applied Health Technology

courseDescription: Learn all the fundamentals of chemistry through this class! This class will be held once a week on Sundays. We will learn different topics each week about periodic table trends, gas laws, acids and bases, and more. At the end of each class, we will have some kind of game like a kahoot to test your knowledge on the concepts. This class will definitely ready you for the concepts you will learn in your chemistry class and you will be able to apply them to other lessons as well.
courseTitle: Regents Chemistry

courseDescription: This class is a software-oriented quick dive into the world of computer science! This is a very beginner course that will go over computer science’s history and an intro to modern programming. The primary goal of the sessions is giving students a taste of computer science knowledge, and a little programming experience, to garner interest in the field. The content will not require any prior knowledge, nor will it cover particularly difficult concepts. We will be focusing on/working with Java.
courseTitle: An Introduction to Computers and Programming in Java

courseDescription: Creating an art portfolio can be immensely stressful, and colleges are frequently vague about what they want to see; consider me your personal guide throughout this application process. Throughout this course, you will come to understand what a "good portfolio" really looks like, and how to balance school requirements with individuality, as well as skill and creativity. This class will also assign small art projects to complete over the week to inspire you, develop your skill, and create potential works for your portfolio! There will be weekly in-class critiques to understand what in your own art to push further, and what to work on. This class is focused on creating a college-ready portfolio, though it can also be inspiring to anyone wishing to create an impressive body of work. Note: this class will be focused on art schools in the U.S, though concepts/assignments can apply worldwide and include liberal art schools.
courseTitle: Portfolio Development: Applying to Art Colleges

courseDescription: Speech 101 is a course that will allow students to become familiar with Speech and Debate while strengthening their skills in public speaking. In this course, students will explore the different events within high school level speech and debate, including Original Oratory, Impromptu, and more! Students will be broken up into individual groups for personalized learning and constructive criticism in order to build on their public speaking skills. Throughout the course, students will be able to participate in a fun, educational setting in which they can grow as eloquent speakers and presenters, comfortable with sharing their thoughts aloud. Please join us! Can’t wait to meet you!
courseTitle: Speech 101

courseDescription: This course discusses various scientific studies surrounding religion and its effects on people and communities over a period of 5 sessions. The objective of this course is to critically evaluate such research, indicated by an understanding of scientific methodology and validity, as well as draw unique conclusions from different perspectives of the same data.
courseTitle: Religion Through the Lens of Science

courseDescription:
Whether you are a 19 year old period veteran or an 11 year old boy not yet experiencing puberty, I want you to know that you belong in our class. Women's Health encompasses a huge number of topics, and I truly believe that you will be able to learn something new in this class, regardless of your age or background. The course covers anatomy, physiology, puberty, ovulation, periods, fertility, sexuality, contraceptives, STIs, abortion, menopause, cancers, violence, doctor/patient trust, and more. If you are at all interested, I urge you to sign up.
     By the end of the course, you will:
1) have a nuanced understanding of women's health at all stages of life
2) feel empowered to take charge of your own healthcare
3) feel more connected with your body if you are female or more empathetic towards the women in your life if you are not female
courseTitle: Women's Health

courseDescription: "Do you wonder how you can savor the power and possibilities of your imagination and creativity in order to live a more fulfilled life?  You're invited to join this workshop series and embark on a transformative journey of emergence, healing, and inner growth; so YOU can move towards a greater sense of well-being! You will understand wellness from a holistic approach (body, mind, emotions, soul). You will also partake in guided meditation, breathwork, and expressive arts-based activities for relaxation, visualization, and as methods to access wisdom, guidance, or symbols.   * No prior artistic experience/knowledge needed! :) * No judgment or critique involved!"
courseTitle: The Art Of Living: Creative Practices For Holistic Wellness

courseDescription:
In this class we will jump into the worlds of Stanislavski, Strasberg, Meisner, and others to bring new energies to debates from the Congress floor in the 1800s, reimagine presidential addresses from the Cold War era, and find the acting style(s) that most fit you!

If you’re like “cool, but who are those people??,” this is the class for you! We’ll start with just that: Who are all these people and what are their performance styles? We will also learn to apply them through practice in class!

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to apply all (we will aim to cover around 7 acting techniques together) of them, but know which one(s) work better for you and how to use them to benefit your speaking, writing, and acting skills!

So, if you choose to join me on this journey, we’ll start each day with a fun acting exercise, practice reading historical texts as scripts each class, and keep each other laughing and having a good time!
courseTitle: Acting Through History

courseDescription: Music is all around us. You can find it in movies, videos, TV shows, games, advertisements, ringtones, plays, and practically anywhere you go, you will hear music. Even in police sirens! The world would not be the same as it is today without music. In fact, we may not even be alive without music. Think theory is boring? Think again. I am a bit of a music nerd and trust me, a couple of lessons with me and you’ll be impressing your friends (as I did) in no time. Join me as we delve deep into the world of music.
courseTitle: The World of Music

courseDescription: This course will mainly focus on some of the applications of computer science in self-driving cars. We will be covering topics such as obstacle detection, algorithms, and autonomy (Artificial Intelligence). This is going to be a brief introduction of self-driving cars, no prior knowledge is required. Hope to see you there!
courseTitle: Computer Science and Self-Driving Cars

courseDescription: This course will cover the basics of international migration, in its laws, faults, and capacities. We will focus on the inherent questions of identity and belonging within the lens of migration, as well as current debates (both in America and abroad) over the role that migration should play in the world today. We will learn about the different types of migration, hear from guest speakers, and engage in critical discussion about the global migration legal regime, migrants as constructed in the public sphere, and current events.
courseTitle: Introduction to Migration

courseDescription: A fun introduction to the STEM through the analysis of common Science Fiction tropes. From the reality vs fiction of laser technology, to the probability of time travel. So come join us as we explore the reality of Science Fiction.
courseTitle: Sci-Fi Connections

courseDescription: From short stories to poetry to creative nonfiction, students will explore a variety of genres. Each class, I will provide short readings to discuss, writing prompts, and feedback. Students should be prepared to share their work with their classmates and engage in discussions. At the end of the course, students will get a chance to publish their work with Wave!
courseTitle: Creative Writing - Exploring the Genres

courseDescription: No matter your age or gender, I want you to know that you belong in our class. Women's Health encompasses a huge number of topics, and I truly believe that you will be able to learn something new, regardless of your background. The course covers anatomy, physiology, puberty, ovulation, periods, fertility, sexuality, contraceptives, STIs, abortion, menopause, cancer prevention, relationship violence, doctor/patient trust, and more. By the end of the course, you will have a nuanced understanding of women's health at all stages of life and feel empowered to take charge of your own healthcare. I also promise to make it fun!
courseTitle: Women's Health

courseDescription: Are you stressed about college applications? Do you find yourself worrying constantly that you’re not qualified to get into your dream school? Are you wondering how on earth you’re going to condense your life’s work and achievements (or the lack thereof) into an application essay? Well if you answered “yes” to any of these questions we are here to help you! College application season is upon us and with the ongoing global pandemic, we understand that it’s harder than normal to connect with resources to help you perfect your applications. Through this course, our goal is to make each and every one of you an expert at marketing your skillsets and thoroughly prepare you for the college application process whether you’re using UC, common, or coalition applications. Our diverse team of instructors is ready to answer any questions you may have whether you’re planning on going to community college and transferring, wondering the difference between a public and private education, thinking about going out of state, or are first-gen and have no idea where to start. See you in class!
courseTitle: Looking Cool for College: Tackling Admissions Essays

courseDescription: In the midst of the Black Lives Matter and defund the police movements, it’s more critical than ever to understand the wider context of the prison-industrial complex and constructions of crime and justice in America. What goes on inside of prisons? What happens after incarcerated folk are released? Who gets to determine what is considered a crime? We will explore these issues in class through collaborative reading and discussion of individual stories and current events, while applying historical, cultural, and interdisciplinary lenses. No prior knowledge is expected; just a curiosity and open-mindedness towards engaging with justice education!
courseTitle: Prison, Punishment and Poverty

courseDescription: In this course, we want to make listening to classical music a more interesting and fun experience for everybody. You will learn about the unique characteristics of the four periods of classical music, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Contemporary, and how to tell them apart. From instrumentation and melody structure to the degree of emotion expressed in the music, there are many unique and interesting ways to differentiate these periods. We will listen to famous works by well-known composers and analyze the pieces. There will be opportunities for students to practice their skills after the ideas are introduced so students can apply their knowledge to a real-life testing/listening situation.
courseTitle: An Introduction to the 4 Periods of Classical Music
prereqs: Students do not need any prior musical experience to take this class, but it will be easier to comprehend if they do.

courseDescription: Greek mythology: where did it go? Chances are, right in your favorite Netflix show. In this course we will examine the hidden prevalence of the ancient Greek lessons in our contemporary forms of entertainment. We will analyze allusions, allegories, inspirations, and the concept of “one story.” Students will learn to spot mythology in their favorite shows and novels, and ask themselves the deeper meaning of these stories. Why do screenwriters and authors repeat the same lessons? Why do we never get tired of hearing the same story? What does this mean for humans as an individual and as a society? This course will inspire deep philosophical thought in the contemporary age.
courseTitle: Greek Mythology & Storytelling

courseDescription:
Ever feel like there’s too much to do? What if I told you there's enough time to finish your homework, chores, AND have fun? Well, it's possible!

We’ll develop your personalized routine so you can do everything you need and want to do. We'll discuss what happiness is and why it can often be so elusive. Just like a recipe, I’ll walk you through the process of identifying your tasks, how long they take, how often they need to be done, and even reflecting on your schedule after you’ve tried it out. Also, I've updated this seminar since last time and can't wait to share my new and improved content!

Let’s schedule happiness (and everything else too)!
courseTitle: Scheduling Happiness 2.0

courseDescription: A course built for students who are interested in studying the Japanese language, but for whatever reason have not started yet. In Beginners' Japanese, students will get a taste of what Japanese study requires, including learning the Hiragana alphabet, 5 very short units of vocabulary, and the some lessons on basic grammar structure. Each lesson will be split into a Hiragana character lesson, a themed vocabulary unit section, and a section in which students will use the vocabulary of the day to form and speak very basic Japanese sentences. In addition, there will be plenty of opportunities to ask questions about extracurricular grammar points, vocabulary, and characters each class. If you're looking for a quick introduction to Japanese language, please join!
courseTitle: Introduction to Japanese

courseDescription: Throughout this seminar, students will have the opportunity to learn various subjects on Veterinary Medicine & Biology. This course will teach students of general resources & emergency surgeries conducted on animals. You'll also gain basic knowledge of how entering the veterinary field is like, and the opportunities offered when you work with animals & study their biological body.
courseTitle: Introduction on the World of Veterinary Medicine

courseDescription: Throughout this seminar, students will have the opportunity to learn various subjects on Veterinary Medicine & Biology. This course will teach students of general resources & emergency surgeries conducted on animals. You'll also gain basic knowledge of how entering the veterinary field is like, and the opportunities offered when you work with animals & study their biological body.
courseTitle: Pokemon Red: Pandora's Cartridge

courseDescription: Have you ever wanted to get your writing published? Although the world of publishing can be intimidating to navigate as a teenager, I have developed a simple, no-stress approach complete with resources, tips, and tricks that will bring you one step closer to becoming a ​published young author! Whether it be a short story, poem, essay, or even a novel, we will walk through the basics of pitching your work to publishers and finding places to submit your work (magazines, anthologies, blogs, and more!).   *No prior writing or publishing experience/knowledge required! :)
courseTitle: How to Get Published as a Teenager!

courseDescription: How can we take environmental matters into our own hands? Let's look at the intersection of marginalized communities and environmental impact.
courseTitle: Personal and Societal Sustainability

courseDescription: This course is designed for high school seniors and juniors working on their college search. Since campus visits have ground to a halt because of the pandemic, it's become harder to truly understand what life as a college student is truly like. In this four-week seminar, we'll discuss topics including dorm living, academics, Greek life, and campus resources that are there to assist you. This course will be presented in a blended format, with synchronous zoom meetings on Saturday afternoons and additional modules recorded for students to view at their convenience. We will also have a number of guest speakers throughout our time together, in order to paint a truly comprehensive portrait of what college life looks like.
courseTitle: College, Unpacked: What Happens Once You're on Campus?

courseDescription:
Whether you are a 19 year old period veteran or an 11 year old boy not yet experiencing puberty, I want you to know that you belong in our class. Women's Health encompasses a huge number of topics, and I truly believe that you will be able to learn something new in this class, regardless of your age or background. The course covers anatomy, physiology, puberty, ovulation, periods, fertility, sexuality, contraceptives, STIs, abortion, menopause, cancers, violence, doctor/patient trust, and more. If you are at all interested, I urge you to sign up.
     By the end of the course, you will:
1) have a nuanced understanding of women's health at all stages of life
2) feel empowered to take charge of your own healthcare
3) feel more connected with your body if you are female or more empathetic towards the women in your life if you are not female
courseTitle: Women's Health

courseDescription: Topics covered in the sessions will include a formative guide, and introduction to the most consequential events in modern day Korean history. Topics included in the three sessions will include, but not limited to, Japanese imperialism of Korea, the rise of the Kim family/dynasty, the cultural prowess of modern day South Korea, and much more.
courseTitle: Contemporary Korea; The Korean War to North and South Korea

courseDescription: Everything you ever wanted to know about DNA, from the ground up. You need no previous experience in genetics. We will start from the beginning , with: The basic chemistry of the DNA molecule, To how DNA is used to make proteins (The Central Dogma), To the discovery and biology of the gene, To the structure of genomes, To the regulation of gene expression, To how a genome can direct the formation of a human (developmental biology), to viruses, to viroids, to incredibly rare inherited diseases, to how to manually engineer entire organisms. Yep. Everything about DNA that I (a DNA fanatic) can think to squeeze into two weeks. It seems like a lot of information, but we will digest it piece by piece with interactive Socrative polls and visuals. By the end of this course, you will be able to grasp the incredibly delicate complexity of genome structure and the coordinated web of activity that is gene expression regulation - you will understand why a banana and a human being can share 60% of their genetic information, yet be completely different life forms. And you will know how to alter the genetic code manually.
courseTitle: DNA and Genomes

courseDescription: Everything you ever wanted to know about DNA, from the ground up. You need no previous experience in genetics. We will start from the beginning , with: The basic chemistry of the DNA molecule, To how DNA is used to make proteins (The Central Dogma), To the discovery and biology of the gene, To the structure of genomes, To the regulation of gene expression, To how a genome can direct the formation of a human (developmental biology), to viruses, to viroids, to incredibly rare inherited diseases, to how to manually engineer entire organisms. Yep. Everything about DNA that I (a DNA fanatic) can think to squeeze into two weeks. It seems like a lot of information, but we will digest it piece by piece with interactive Socrative polls and visuals. By the end of this course, you will be able to grasp the incredibly delicate complexity of genome structure and the coordinated web of activity that is gene expression regulation - you will understand why a banana and a human being can share 60% of their genetic information, yet be completely different life forms. And you will know how to alter the genetic code manually.
courseTitle: Introduction to the First World War (History Discussion/Seminar)

courseDescription: Do you have an interest in politics? Would you like to construct a foundation within the subject while also studying real-world examples of its practical application? Well, you’ve come to the right place. This class will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the basic structures of a government to the diversity of political ideology. We will look at countries like China, the U.K., the U.S., and others that manifest some basic commonalities of governments around the world in conjunction with their own unique aspects. We will also attempt to explore the history and impacts of policies surrounding contemporary issues around elections, education, healthcare, and foreign policy. Each day of instruction will be divided by topical relevance to the basic functions of a government, domestic policy, foreign policy, elections/campaigns, and political ideology. Activities, such as extended discussions guided by thematic questions, will be conducted regularly during the class to create an atmosphere of interactivity and comfortability. In this class, you will also be responsible for creating and presenting a final project on a relevant political issue and proposing a solution to said issue. To give you time in doing so, the last 15-30 minutes of each class day will be allocated for independent work and research on an approved topic. The main goal behind this project and the aforementioned class discussions would be to inspire you to pursue a career in debate, political science, or an associated field that tests your creativity and critical thinking skills. You will be tested on whether you can create both creative and pragmatic solutions to issues our modern world is facing today in the realm of politics. Lastly, this class will also lead you to attaining a broader understanding of the ideologies that drive political discourse today and where they come from within our socioeconomic environments.
courseTitle: Political Theory and its Application in Contemporary Society

courseDescription: The Generation of Change is a two-week workshop which aims to prepare participants from a variety of backgrounds for effective advocacy work. Through education and experience, students have the opportunity to study relevant topics, learn from leading professionals, and develop their own skills and initiatives to become better leaders of change in their own communities.
courseTitle: The Generation of Change

courseDescription: In this course, we will focus on different crafts and ways to use simple materials to create masterpieces. Each class we will learn a new set of activities to broaden your skills! These include watercolor, cards, making pom-poms, journaling, hand lettering, and more! I will be leading tutorials each week and helping you all with your creations.
courseTitle: Crafting, Card Making & Journaling

courseDescription: Pharmacists are everywhere! But what do these mystical people do and how can YOU use pharmacists to enhance your health? In this course, we will cover the basics of the profession of pharmacy, the numerous paths available to pharmacists, and the impact of pharmacists on public health. Along our journey into pharmacy, we will teach you how to use pharmacists and the resources available to you to advocate for and take charge of your health and wellbeing.
courseTitle: The Legal Drug Dealers of America: Pharmacists

courseDescription: In this course, teenagers will be learning how to start a business and grow that business BY THEMSELF. Teens will also learn how to market, manage, and implement their ideas into their business. In addition to that, they will learn how to conduct research for competing companies and how to work around that. This seminar is highly suggested for those that have a passion for business, want to help out the community, and wish to implement their ideas at an early age. During this course, students will: Develop their leadership qualities Learn how to independently manage a business Learn how to manage a team
courseTitle: How to Start & Grow a Business as a Teen

courseDescription: This course is perfect for you if you're someone who wants to build better habits for a better version of yourself this 2021. Through this online course, you will learn the importance of personal finances, time management, and a “purposeful” morning routine. If you love gamified and interactive classes, this one is for you! No prior knowledge or experience is required.
courseTitle: Building Better Habits for a Better Year

courseDescription: Tired of relying on others to make you smile? Your happiness is in your own hands.   In our fast paced world of school and chores, it often feels like there's too much to do and not enough time.   Join us in this 2-part seminar as we talk about:   1) How to Dismantle Overwhelm with HOPE - Time Management Strategies 2) How to Prioritize Your Own Happiness & Still Get Everything Else Done - Mindset & Boundaries   If you’ve joined Scheduling Happiness in prior sessions, it would be great to see your familiar face as we are diving deeper into these topics.
courseTitle: How to Make Your Own Happiness

courseDescription: In this class we will explore the dynasties of China, going through around 2 dynasties during each class. We will be focusing on the interesting stories and people and their major legacies, instead of minor details. We will be talking about tragic stories of love, motivational stories of emperors who started at the bottom of the social ladder, and funny stories where we wonder why people ever thought that was a good idea. We will be going through famous lines of ancient Chinese poetry, discussing mysteries still unsolved to this day, and visit places still impacted by events that happened thousands of years ago. We will meet talented scholars, powerful rulers, and admirable advisors. But we will also relate with ordinary people: kids who don't want to learn, mad parents, betrayal from friends and lovers, and people contemplating the meaning of human existence. Through this class you will realize that history is not about fishbowls and DBQ's, instead it's about the emotions and aspirations of real people like us, who have people we care about, things we want to do, and changes we want to cause.
courseTitle: 5000 Years In 5 Weeks: Before and After the Chinese Dynasties

courseDescription: This course will cover basic Russian vocabulary. We'll teach greeting phrases, numbers, days of the week, hobbies, and food. We'll also mentally travel to Russia each week and watch cartoons (including the Russian Winnie Pooh!), show you our favorite homemade recipes, and talk about the Sochi Olympic Games. There'll be discussions about Russian books and art. No previous language learning experience is necessary, and we welcome everyone!
courseTitle: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture

courseDescription: Have you ever wondered about what the civilizations that shaped America were like? Are you curious about how the political systems of people who lived thousands of years ago are still impacting society today? If so, this is the class for you! In this seminar, we will discuss ancient Roman and Greek history, including elements of philosophy and mythology. Starting in 510 B.C.E with the founding of the Roman Republic, we will discuss the various political leaders, wars, and government establishments. For the Greek curriculum, we will focus on Athenian democracy and culture. After discussing what the governments of Athens and Rome looked like, we will take a look at the philosophical ideas that contributed to their constructions, specifically those outlined in Plato’s Republic. Finally, we will turn to the legacy of these civilizations and their impact on today’s world.
courseTitle: Exploring Antiquity: Greek and Roman Politics

courseDescription: Have you ever wanted to change history? To alter world events? Join Samarth Desai and Nick Danby (former teachers of "Great Speeches of History") as they travel back in time. In this six-session seminar, students will play famous figures in historical "crisis simulations" as they decide what course of action their country should pursue. Students will be able to serve as ambassadors, cabinet secretaries, ambassadors, or even the British prime minister! Before each simulation, students will be given a historical role and the crisis's background information. During class, the instructors will brief these "new leaders" and begin the hour-long simulation. Afterward, the class will discuss what they learned and compare what they did to what really happened. In the process, students will learn about teamwork, foreign policy, American history, the challenges of leadership, reasoning from history, and how to make difficult decisions in their future.
courseTitle: Making History: Simulating Foreign Policy Crises

courseDescription:
This class teaches students to code in HTML and CSS through unique activities and engagement. By the end of the class, students will have built an entire professional looking website of their choice!
Beginners are welcome!
courseTitle: HTML/CSS: Building a Website

courseDescription: This seminar will be about creativity and innovation. In the upcoming five lessons, I along with participants will travel in the world of our imagination and learn some key lessons from different stories of innovation of creative and genius people ever born on this planet. The participants will test their creative skills through online and offline assessments. They will also be able to create their own Personal Creativity Machine (PCM). The more they use this, the better creative and innovative ideas will be discovered by them. In this seminar, the audiences will understand how our traditional academic systems are gradually killing our creativity skills when we grow up. They will also find possible ways to get rid of this conventional chain of rules. They will also learn about the very effective Zi-Zo-Zi method for discovering and delivering ideas. Participants will also learn about the story behind some common objects which we use in our daily life. At the ending part of the seminar, a group activity will occur. I will assign 8-9 current or evolving earth problems to the participants divided into groups. I will ask them to come up with some wild but implementable ideas to solve these problems. We all know that creativity is a life long lesson. It can not be achieved within just five classes. But I believe after taking part in this seminar, every learner will understand the importance of creativity and innovation in our life. They will get a chance to practice these skills individually and within a group in different phases of the seminar. I am really excited to meet with the learners or future global citizens who will solve critical problems with their sharp knowledge and creative minds. See you at the seminar.
courseTitle: Creativity and innovation: How to think like a genius
prereqs: Aspiration and willpower to learn anything, do many things and achieve everything in life

courseDescription: As compared to the actual world, we live comparatively guarded lives within the confines of our educational institutions. It therefore becomes important that students have a general idea of what to expect once they inevitably enter the corporate world. This seminar series will introduce you to the basics of your professional life, irregardless of the field you choose.
courseTitle: Foraying into the Professional World

courseDescription: This course will provide an introduction to the form of "zines," or small-circulation, hand-made magazines. In this course, students will learn about the history of zines and be introduced to different online resources to make and share zines. By the end of the course, students will be familiar with zines and create a zine of their own to share with the class.
courseTitle: Let's Make a Zine!

courseDescription: If you think the school system needs to change, you’ve come to the right place! Through meaningful dialogue centering YOUR educational experiences, we will build relationships that facilitate transformation of self and the collective community. This class will use a social justice lens, taking a multi-media, discussion-based approach. Through practicing courageous vulnerability, you will be empowered to take ownership over your education. By the end of the seminar, you will see education in a new light and imagine the possibilities of education we can work toward.
courseTitle: Transforming Ourselves, Transforming Education

courseDescription: Stressed out about everything going on in the world? Feeling alone and misunderstood?   Come join us during this 3-part series to explore:  1) what happiness means to each of us,  2) how we can take control of our time to do what we need & want to do, and  3) why social media is actually a good thing.   If you’ve joined Scheduling Happiness in prior sessions, it would be great to see your familiar face as we are now diving even deeper into these topics!
courseTitle: Scheduling Happiness 3.0

courseDescription: Since the first detection of gravitational waves by the LIGO Collaboration in 2015, awarded the 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics, the field of gravitational wave astronomy has exploded. In this seminar, you'll learn how and why astrophysicists want to detect ripples in spacetime itself from colliding black holes and neutron stars, requiring some of the world's most precise measurements. We'll explore what gravitational waves are, how we detect them, the extreme systems that produce them, what they can tell us about the universe's monsters, and the awesome things we've learned so far.
courseTitle: The Universe's Hidden Monsters: Exploring the Gravitational Wave Zoo

courseDescription: Broadway is home to more than forty theaters, with the majority hosting shows with mainly white actors telling white stories. People of color on Broadway are often only present as token characters and understudies. This seminar will look into the roles that actors of color fulfill in Broadway musicals, as well as why the current systems are harmful, and how the institution of Broadway has racist roots and processes that continue to shut out creatives of color. The treatment of specific racial groups will be discussed, as well as which shows highlight performers of color and how. Examples include Hamilton, Hairspray, Hadestown, and more.
courseTitle: Leading, Supporting, Invisible Roles: People of Color and Broadway Musicals

courseDescription: Intro to Mechanics is designed to provide students with a strong physics foundation and, more importantly, a passion for the subject. Through interactive lectures and lab demonstrations, this class introduces two fundamental topics in mechanics: kinematics and dynamics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding. This class aims to be fun and inspiring; my goal is for each and every student to come away enthusiastic about physics and able to recognize and apply concepts to their everyday experiences.
courseTitle: Physics: Introduction to Mechanics

courseDescription: This course will explore the information needed to secure funding and lower costs for college. It will explore how funding is determined, cover the types of funding, and include personalized instruction that will start the students on their funding searches.
courseTitle: Secure the Bag - Financial Aid and Getting that College $$$$

courseDescription: This is a class dedicated to discussing Belgian colonialism in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, the Congolese Wars, and modern Central African politics. We will discuss the impacts of colonialism, what justice looks like in the aftermath of genocide, the importance of studying African history, the role of the Western world in foreign conflicts, and many other relevant issues
courseTitle: Legacies of Colonialism: Contemporary Central African History

courseDescription: Until 1905, physicists' conception of Space was that of a static backdrop against which the drama of the Universe played out to the steady tick of Time as its metronome; a meter was a meter and a second was a second. When a certain German patent-clerk showed up on the scene with a wild haircut and crazy idea, however, that all changed. In this course, we will explore Albert Einstein's 1905 Theory of Special Relativity that changed our outlook on Spacetime -- the very fabric of the Universe -- forever. Though most people are familiar with its founder, few are actually aware of the mind-bending consequences that Special Relativity implies for us as inhabitants of the cosmos. Over the next five weeks, we will endeavor to explore the subject at an introductory level accessible to anyone with a little algebra and geometry in their back pocket. We will derive firsthand how Space and Time are not the fixed stage which we imagine them to be, but rather dynamic and shifting dimensions that compose a very different underlying reality than the one we are used to in our everyday lives.
courseTitle: Rethinking Space and Time: A Brief Look Into Special Relativity
prereqs: None absolutely required; a basic understanding of Geometry/Trigonometry and Algebra II or the equivalent will be helpful.  Any class in introductory physics (particularly mechanics) will also be helpful, but we will endeavor to approach material from an introductory standpoint in all cases.  If you are ever having trouble following the math, please let us know and we will help you out!

courseDescription: From statistical concepts to applications on real-world datasets, this course is a great introduction to the world of statistical analysis. Data analytical skills have become essential for careers in science, engineering, business and all other aspects of life. This course aims to promote learning and applying processes in extracting meaningful knowledge from data, growing increasingly important in an era of big data. Students learn descriptive statistics, data visualization, and inferential statistics, that they can then apply to a project of their own interest. No prior experience necessary!
courseTitle: Statistical Analysis in Data Science

courseDescription: Do you want to learn how to eat healthier? Lose weight? Build muscle? Or just feel better in your body overall? Then "Fitness, Nutrition, Mental Health: Keys to a Healthy Lifestyle" is the class for you! Come with your own personal goals or interests and I promise I will help you achieve them. You will learn about proper caloric intake, the macros and micros of food, and different diets. We will go over different types of workouts and their benefits and drawbacks. But most importantly, we will discuss the mental aspects of embarking on these personal journeys, making sure we have strong mental foundations so that we can safely achieve our goals.
courseTitle: Fitness, Nutrition, Mental Health: Keys to a Healthy Lifestyle

courseDescription: Generation Z is the most diverse, inclusive generation to date. Learn how to use your talents to start a movement. This is not your average community service. This is activism, and the possibilities are limitless. The world is now listening to Generation Z. How will we respond? Leave this course with a PSA script in hand and insight about how to use film and media to create social change.
courseTitle: #GENZSPEAKS: Activism through Art

courseDescription: The brain is arguably the most important part of the human body, as it plays a role in nearly every aspect of human life. The brain is divided into four lobes, and in this course, we will dedicate four sessions to delving into each respective lobe. We will cover a large variety of topics from voluntary movement to unconscious thinking and answer any burning questions you may have about your brain. We will even find fun ways for you to get involved with in-class activities, making everything that’s going on up there a little easier to understand. We hope you’ll join us on this journey of navigating the human brain!
courseTitle: Navigating Your Brain

courseDescription: Have you ever wondered how an archaeologist studies ancient history through the stunning tombs of emperors and kings? In this course of Chinese Archaeology 101, I will lead you through the process of opening up an ancient Chinese tomb and what you can learn about an ancient civilization based on the artifacts inside. You will also be introduced to many areas of Chinese culture which you may not have yet known. During each session, we will be exploring the tomb of one historical figure to understand them as an individual and societal values and beliefs as a whole. If you are interested in learning about ancient Chinese artifacts and what they were used for, sign up for this course and I hope to see you there!
courseTitle: Chinese Archaeology 101

courseDescription: Ever wondered about the core principles of data science? Want to learn how to apply concepts in calculus and probability you’ve used in math classes to real-world problems? Learn a bee coding language? Then join this workshop for more info!
courseTitle: Introduction to Computation Modelling with Julia

courseDescription: Broadway is home to more than forty theaters, with the majority hosting shows with mainly white actors telling white stories. People of color on Broadway are often only present as token characters and understudies. This seminar will look into the roles that actors of color fulfill in Broadway musicals, as well as why the current systems are harmful, and how the institution of Broadway has racist roots and processes that continue to shut out creatives of color. The treatment of specific racial groups will be discussed, as well as which shows highlight performers of color and how. Examples include Hamilton, Hairspray, Hadestown, and more.
courseTitle: Leading, Supporting, Invisible Roles: People of Color and Broadway Musicals

courseDescription: A course built for students who are interested in studying the Japanese language, but for whatever reason have not started yet. In Beginners' Japanese, students will get a taste of what Japanese study requires. The course focuses on tips for speaking Japanese and improving your Japanese accent, as well as tips for study of written Japanese. If you're looking for a quick introduction to Japanese language, please join!
courseTitle: Beginners' Japanese

courseDescription: Do you ever look at someone and wonder, "wow, they are really confident and sound like they know what they're talking about", and when you try to emulate that, you feel intimidated and at a loss for words? You aren’t alone! Join this workshop to not only learn how to win in a debate and give public speeches, but also to resonate that confidence in everyday life and conversations, make heads turn when you walk into a room, and win hearts without even saying a word. Leave a conversation leaving the other person wanting more. Join me to learn how!
courseTitle: Confidence, Public speaking and debate

courseDescription: In this seminar, we will be covering 5 important organ systems in the human body: the respiratory, circulatory, digestive, immune, and nervous systems. Each week, we will be exploring a new system, and incorporating interactive activities such as trivia, quizzes, and kahoots! At the end of the month, we will have a class to discuss pathophysiology, including how COVID-19 affects our organ systems.
courseTitle: Introduction to Physiology and Organ Systems

courseDescription: Creativity brings novelty and uniqueness in our thinking process and activities. It is widening the range of choices. Creativity and innovation are two important catalysts which make us more developed civilization at present. These are the most vital soft skills that will bring success for you in the long run. But our academic life really hampers our creativity skills. In this seminar, we will learn how to break this chain of behavior and test our limit of knowledge with different hands on exercises in each sessions. We will also learn the process of generating and implementing unique and world changing ideas through different inspiring stories of creative, innovative and successful people ever lived on this world.
courseTitle: Creativity and Innovation: How to think like a genius 2.0

courseDescription: Still struggling with your college applications? Haven’t finished your personal statement? How about your supplements? Do you know where to start? If you answered no to any of the previous questions, this course was made just for you! The main objective of this seminar is to supply you with the essential strategies and knowledge that will help you create effective and successful college essays for your application. We will also be discussing aspects of the application that are commonly overlooked by students, such as the waitlist process, admissions interviews, and other parts of the Common Application. We'll be offering one-on-one feedback to cater directly to any questions or concerns you may have.
courseTitle: College Process 101: 2 Months until the Deadline

courseDescription: The Gordian Knot, an ancient puzzle that marked a legendary chapter of Alexander the Great, has become the term used to describe complex and unsolvable problems. In life there is no doubt that problems exist all over the place. From the most complicated questions such as trying to prove the Riemann Hypothesis or discussing the meaning of life, to the more mundane problems such as trying to open a jar or simply figuring out what you're gonna eat for the night, the solution may not always be easy to find. In this course, we will be exploring a variety of problem solving methods while looking over a myriad of complicated problems that exists around the world.
courseTitle: Problem Solving: Unraveling the Gordian Knot

courseDescription: Are you stressed about college applications? Do you find yourself worrying constantly that you’re not qualified to get into your dream school? Are you wondering how on earth you’re going to condense your life’s work and achievements (or the lack thereof) into an application essay? Well if you answered “yes” to any of these questions we are here to help you! College application season is upon us and with the ongoing global pandemic, we understand that it’s harder than normal to connect with resources to help you perfect your applications. Through this course, our goal is to make each and every one of you an expert at marketing your skillsets and thoroughly prepare you for the college application process whether you’re using UC, common, or coalition applications. Our diverse team of instructors is ready to answer any questions you may have whether you’re planning on going to community college and transferring, wondering the difference between a public and private education, thinking about going out of state, or are first-gen and have no idea where to start. See you in class!
courseTitle: Looking Cool for College: Tackling Admissions Essays

courseDescription: This class will be a hands on learning experience in early stage startup formation. We start from scratch with brainstorming problems and solutions, then learn how to prototype our solution and test with potential consumers - crucial skills for any entrepreneur!
courseTitle: Early Stage Entrepreneurship

courseDescription: You may know a fair share of artists -- Michelangelo, Picasso, Monet, Van Gogh… But how many female artists can you name off the top of your head? The answer is: NOT ENOUGH! Traditional art history has ignored the work of female artists, therefore our cultural understanding of artistic genius is overwhelmingly male (despite the arts being long-associated with femininity). Women artists have always existed, yet they were either ignored or not credited as serious innovators. In this workshop you will definitely hear some facts to trigger your feminist consciousness, but most importantly you will leave feeling inspired and knowing the names/artwork of LOTS of female artists throughout history.
courseTitle: Know Their Names: Female Artists Throughout History

courseDescription: Assassinations, Vietnam, protests, crackdowns, and a political party realignment: all of these marked 1968 as a watershed moment in American history. This course will examine several major events of the year through a combination of lectures, readings of primary source documents, and guided discussions. By the end, students will understand the significance of this monumental year, and how it continues to shape our culture and politics today. Anyone with an interest in developing their skill of critical historical thinking is encouraged to apply.
courseTitle: 1968: America’s Year of Crisis
prereqs: Some basic level of US history course

courseDescription: Coming soon!
courseTitle: Introduction to Understanding Email Box

courseDescription: Explore important fields of mathematics such as probability, combinatorics, and geometry through their applications to burritos, enchiladas, and other tasty adventures!
courseTitle: The Mathematics of Burritos, Enchiladas, and more!

courseDescription: Want to learn how to pursue a career in sustainability? Want to create a project that benefits your community? At "Paths to Sustainability," we'll teach you the basics of sustainability, have professors and people from diverse career fields come in to share their stories on how they incorporate sustainability in their roles, and finally, you'll be paired up in teams to solve issues in your community!
courseTitle: Paths to Sustainability

courseDescription: Love animated films? Curious to know how filters actually work? In this course, we'll answer these questions, and more! From the tools and mechanisms of digital art to the foundations of lighting and shape techniques of art, you'll learn how to use free, phone-friendly apps to create your own drawings, comics, and even animations. The program we will use is Ibispaint X, which is free for iPad, iPhone, other touch screen devices, and the computer. At the end of this program, students will have knowledge on how to use them and apply traditional art techniques onto a digital setting. Get ready to color your screen!
courseTitle: Digital Art: Recoloring the Screen

courseDescription: Have you ever had a moment where you wanted to draw something but felt you didn’t have the “artistic talent” to do so? Well, scroll no further. This course will cover the basics of drawing still life, a medium undervalued by many, but catalyzes many artistic endeavours. You will learn the basics of the medium, perspective, value, untold tips and tricks and have the opportunity to create your own still life drawing by the end of the course. Upon completing this course, you will no longer see the world the same way as you did before. All you need is a pencil, paper and a positive attitude!
courseTitle: Introduction to Drawing Still Life

courseDescription: Cultural competence is essential to the way we relate to one another, in both the professional world and our personal friendships. In this course, we will define culture and discuss how it relates to our mental health experiences. Together, we'll brainstorm strategies to overcome racial barriers to mental health resources and create resources for our own communities! As we discuss and unpack mental health topics from racial trauma, to erasure, to resilience, we will raise up forgotten voices to build a future where we help people better, together. ***Content warning: While I strive to make this course as engaging and uplifting as possible, we will discuss heavy topics such as racism, trauma, mental illness, and suicide. There will not be graphic images or descriptions of violence or suffering, but these topics may still be uncomfortable to engage with, so I would strongly encourage you to keep this in mind. Content and trigger warnings will be used throughout each session.
courseTitle: A Culturally Competent Guide to Mental Health

courseDescription: What comes to your mind when you think of a nurse? Is it the image of your school nurse taking your weight and height? Or is it the thought of a bedside caregiver in a hospital? Chances are that if these are the only things you think nurses do, you don’t actually know what the nursing profession is all about! Did you know that you can even travel around the world as a nurse? In this course, I will teach you all about nursing, from the misconceptions of nursing to all the career opportunities you can pursue as a nurse! If I have convinced you to become a nurse, I am going to provide you a step-by-step path to pursue this profession, starting now as a high schooler!
courseTitle: What is Nursing?: A Comprehensive Guide for High Schoolers

courseDescription: Learning to program is the modern day equivalent of having a superpower - it opens up an infinite amount of possibility and opportunity. As our world becomes more technological, people with programming expertise become more and more valuable.   This course is an introduction to basic programming concepts and computational thinking, covering types, control flow, and object-oriented programming. No prior experience is required.
courseTitle: Programming with Python: A Painless Introduction

courseDescription: Want to create a tangible positive impact on your community, but don’t know how to? In this interactive course, you’ll learn how to identify local issues and develop solutions for them, write policy recommendations, lobby public officials for the implementation of your recommendations, and campaign digitally to bolster support for your lobbying efforts. You will receive plenty of detailed and concise resources to help you through the process!
courseTitle: Solving Civic Issues: Policy-Making and Lobbying

courseDescription: Heard of the infamous Monty Hall problem? Ever wondered why a candidate no one expected to win ended up being the President of the USA? Questioned why scientists could not prevent a major space shuttle catastrophe? In this course, we will give the students an insight into Probability and Statistics and an answer to all these questions! By focusing on Statistics and Statistical Programming, we hope to give the students an idea of both what statistics is and where every statistics project starts. We will investigate the most famous Paradoxes and Riddles in Probability and show the students that Statistics is interesting & fun. Nowadays, with the increasing amount of data available, Statistics allows us to understand every topic much more deeply. Statistics is a crucial part of many discoveries in science and helps with making informed decisions and predictions. No prior coding experience is needed! Please note that you will need a PC to download RStudio.
courseTitle: Introduction to Probability, Statistics, and R Programming Language

courseDescription: Intro to Mechanics is designed to provide students with a strong physics foundation and, more importantly, a passion for the subject. Through interactive lectures and lab demonstrations, this class introduces two fundamental topics in mechanics: kinematics and dynamics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding. This class aims to be fun and inspiring; my goal is for each and every student to come away enthusiastic about physics and able to recognize and apply concepts to their everyday experiences.
courseTitle: Physics: Introduction to Mechanics

courseDescription: From the Elven languages of Tolkien to the modern Game of Thrones’ Dothraki, constructed languages are all over the place in modern fantasy and sci-fi. For writers, GMs, and other hobbyists, making a language might sound fascinating, but also close to impossible. Language is so broad, complex, and multilayered that beginning conlangers might have no idea where to start. However, conlanging is not actually as hard as it looks. With this step-by-step course, students can create their own proto-language in five weeks, along with a simple writing system and maybe even a fictional people to use it. This course is for conlanging beginners; no prior experience is necessary, either with conlanging or with linguistics.
courseTitle: Invent Your Own Language: Conlanging for Beginners

courseDescription: How does a quarter of a million dollars sound? Well each year, the Regeneron Science Talent Search gives away a grand prize of $250,000 and many more monetary and prestigious prizes. That winner could be you. Join me in this 5 week journey where we will explore the scientific process, conduct our own research projects, and hone our presentation skills- all culminating in a mock science fair. The world of science fair can open so many doors for you- wether that be a network, college admissions, notarity, or, yes, even money. Science fair has changed my own life- maybe it could change yours too. So together, let's learn HOW TO SCIENCE FAIR!
courseTitle: How To Science Fair

courseDescription: By the end of Financial Literacy 101, you will know the basics of investing, paying taxes, building good credit, buying a home, and so much more! We will discuss important strategies needed for having a solid and secure financial plan in the future. Knowing how to budget and manage your money is a key life skill to staying out of debt and being financially stress-free.
courseTitle: Financial Literacy 101

courseDescription: Do you have an interest in politics? If so, welcome! This workshop will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the structural to the intellectual components. We will look at countries like China and the U.S. in order to look at policies in action, analyzing both the intended and unintended consequences. Activities, such as discussions and policy research, will be conducted regularly during the workshop to create an atmosphere of interactivity. For each workshop, policy proposals will be constructed by students as to utilize the knowledge garnered during the lessons.
courseTitle: Political Theory and its Application in Contemporary Society

courseDescription: Do you have an interest in politics? Would you like to construct a foundation within the subject while also studying real-world examples of its practical application? Well, you’ve come to the right place. This class will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the basic structures of a government to the diversity of political ideology. We will look at countries like China, the U.K., the U.S., and others that manifest some basic commonalities of governments around the world in conjunction with their own unique aspects. We will also attempt to explore the history and impacts of policies surrounding contemporary issues around elections, education, healthcare, and foreign policy. Each day of instruction will be divided by topical relevance to the basic functions of a government, domestic policy, foreign policy, elections/campaigns, and political ideology. Activities, such as extended discussions guided by thematic questions, will be conducted regularly during the class to create an atmosphere of interactivity and comfortability. In this class, you will also be responsible for creating and presenting a final project on a relevant political issue and proposing a solution to said issue. To give you time in doing so, the last 15-30 minutes of each class day will be allocated for independent work and research on an approved topic. The main goal behind this project and the aforementioned class discussions would be to inspire you to pursue a career in debate, political science, or an associated field that tests your creativity and critical thinking skills. You will be tested on whether you can create both creative and pragmatic solutions to issues our modern world is facing today in the realm of politics. Lastly, this class will also lead you to attaining a broader understanding of the ideologies that drive political discourse today and where they come from within our socioeconomic environments.
courseTitle: Political Theory and its Application in Contemporary Society

courseDescription: Do you have an interest in politics? If so, welcome! This workshop will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the structural to the intellectual components. We will look at countries like China and the U.S. in order to look at policies in action, analyzing both the intended and unintended consequences. Activities, such as discussions and policy research, will be conducted regularly during the workshop to create an atmosphere of interactivity. For each workshop, policy proposals will be constructed by students as to utilize the knowledge garnered during the lessons.
courseTitle: Introduction to Political Theory
